original_title: Sri Lanka EPF not to accept DDR until superannuation tax is hiked
original_body_lines: ECONOMYNEXT – Sri Lanka’s Employees Provident Fund will not take up an offer to exchange rupee bonds until a tax is hiked on superannuation funds, lawyers said in a preliminary court hearing on domestic debt restructure.

A beneficiary of the Employee’s Provident Fund went to court against the restructuring of bonds in the EPF saying it was iniquitous and sought an interim order preventing the Monetary Board of the central bank from taking up the offer.
Superannuation funds that do not take up the offer will face a 30 percent tax, up from the current 14 percent.
President’s Counsel K Kanag-Isvaran, acting for Central Bank Governor Nandalal Weerasinghe said there was nothing to halt as the Monetary Board will not take accept the offer until taxes are changed.

Counsel M A Sumanthiran said the petitioner appreciated the position of the EPF not taking the offer to exchange debt until the tax hike was passed in parliament, but that the Monetary Board had a conflict of interest with members involved in debt restructuring and managing the EPF.
Related Sri Lanka EPF beneficiaries counsel argue courts can intervene on DDR
The Finance Ministry said Friday that the deadline to exchange debt was extended from August 11 to August 28.
Related Sri Lanka extends deadline to restructure EPF debt to Aug 28
The bill to hike taxes on the superannuation funds was tabled in parliament but has not been passed. (Colombo/Aug11/2023)
